Estas mujeres tienen distintos tipos de actividades que realizan para generar ingresos, entre ellas podemos citar: venta de comestibles, frutas, verduras, algunas tienen despensas, otras venden ropas, lencerías y otras (la mayoría) se dedican al reciclaje.

El deseo de progresar que tienen estas mujeres es admirable, y se evidencia en el empeño que cada una dedica a su labor diario, como comité hablamos de un grupo bastante responsable en los pagos de sus cuotas y en sus ahorros.

El crédito que recibirán cada una de estas mujeres será destinado a la inversión de sus negocios, comprando mercaderías como azúcar, leche, productos enlatados, refrescos, compra de ingredientes para la elaboración de comidas como carne, verduras, frutas y también para la compra de artículos para reciclar como botellas de vidrios, plásticos y papeles.

loans.use: Purchase of coffee, sugar, flour, fruits, vegetables, canned goods, home products, recycling supplies such as plastic, cardboard and glass bottles.

loans.name: Proyecto Rima Group

texts.en:
Yoni is a 39-year old woman who lives in a very poor community called Proyecto Rima, or Project Rima, on the outskirts of the capital Santo Domingo.

Yoni is a Haitian immigrant, and lives with her husband and four children in a small home.  She recently started a small business selling fresh fruit to her community members She is requesting a loan so that she has can buy larger quantities of higher quality fruit and travel to heavily transited areas to sell her wares.  In the Dominican Republic, it is very common for people to buy pieces of fresh fruit on the corners as they walk to work, their homes, or simply when they are out and about.  The money from this loan will help her make more money by enabling her to sell in a different location and  to buy enough fruit to meet the demand she will face.

She hopes that her business will continue to grow with the help of this loan, and that with the profits she realizes, she will be able to help her children study more.  It is her goal to always have a steady job, and to always work to provide for her family.
 
On behalf of everyone here at Esperanza International, and from Yoni herself, we thank you for your support with this micro loan!

loans.use: To purchase of higher quality fruits and vegetables.

loans.name: Phon

texts.en: Phon S. is a widow and lives in the Siem Reap province of Cambodia. She is currently unemployed and, instead, manages her family household and tries to help her children who all must work. Phon S. has two sons and two daughters. The two sons, pictured with Phon S. in the photo, are both construction workers, while the daughters work as waitresses. Every day, Phon's daughters have to commute a fairly long distance to work. She therefore hopes to receive a loan to be able to buy a motorbike that they could share for the daily commute.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is married with two children, both of whom are currently in school. She is a thirty four year old business woman. She started trading twelve years ago and she enjoys trading. She trades in garment clothes and lace materials.

Gladys believes in hard work and dedication. She amassed lots of marketing experience, making her one of the successful traders in Obuasi market. She believes that with this loan she will be better able to supply her customers with quality products. She hopes to raise increased income, since quality comes with price. She wants to use the loan to buy more pieces of garment clothes and lace materials.

She belongs to the community group called St. Benedict Trust Group. Members in this group guarantee for one another as social collateral to access loans and peer pressure to repay the loans. Gladys is in the photo, taken during her group meeting.

loans.use: To buy more pieces of garment clothes and lace materials.

loans.name: Comité San Antonio Group

texts.es:
The San Antonio group was established on 26 May 2008.  This group was organised thanks to the fact that the current President, Felicia González (dress-maker and hairdresser), approached Fundación Paraguaya to ask for an assessment as she had previously participated in another group and wanted to belong to a new one together with her neighbours.  The meeting with the organisation was a success and this is how today 15 women are working together in solidarity.
The members of this group are using their loan to fund different activities such as : sale of cleaning products, sale of eggs, snacks, meals and drinks, sewing, sale of honey and honeycakes.
The same members participate in weekly meetings and undertake activities to collect funds.  The group works co-operatively, demonstrating companionship and solidarity.
 Felicia, Bernarda, Cinthya, Sonia, Felicita, Liliana, Justa, María, Ana, Lourdes, Elsi, Lucila, Diana, Pablina and Valeriana now want a loan to invest in their respective businesses and in this way they will be able to increase their production and their incomes.
Translated from the Spanish by Katy Long, Kiva Volunteer
El Grupo denominado San Antonio, se conformó en fecha 26 de mayo de2008, dicho grupo fue organizado, gracias a que la actual presidenta del grupo, Felicia González de profesión modista y peluquera, se acercó a la Fundación Paraguaya, para pedir asesoramiento ya que ella, anteriormente ya participo en otro grupo y quería conformar uno nuevo junto con sus vecinas. La reunión de organización fue un éxito y es así como hoy 15 señoras están juntas trabajando solidariamente.
Las integrantes de este grupo destinan su crédito a diferentes actividades  tales como: venta de productos de limpieza, venta de huevos, golosinas, comidas y bebidas, trabajos de costura, venta de miel y tortas de miel.
Las mismas participan activamente en las reuniones  semanales y realizan actividades para recaudar fondos. El grupo trabaja en forma conjunta, demuestran compañerismo y solidaridad.
Las señoras Felicia, Bernarda, Cinthya, Sonia, Felicita, Liliana, Justa, María, Ana, Lourdes, Elsi, Lucila, Diana, Pablina y Valeriana hoy desean un crédito para poder invertirlos en sus respectivos negocios ya que de este modo ellas lograrán aumentar su producción e ingresos.

loans.use: Purchase threads and materials, cleaning products, meat, flour, noodles, oil, honey, eggs, dairy products, snacks, sugar, sweets etc.

loans.name: Ashura

texts.en:
Ashura is 26 years old. She is married with one child aged 4 years old. She has been a food seller since April 2008. Every day, she works from 7am to 6pm at her business and can earn a monthly profit of about US$ 80 from her sales.

Ashura is now requesting a loan to buy more food items for her business.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Mrs. San Kunthea's Village Bank Group

texts.en:
The Village Bank president for this group is Mrs. San K. who has been selected by twenty members in Koh Kaev Kraom Village in Kandal Province. She is currently in the business of selling grocery items and she is now requesting a loan to purchase more grocery products to expand her inventory while her business is going well.

Mrs. San K. is 29 years old and she is married to Mr. Huon Heat who is a farmer. She has two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the younger one is too young to work or study because that child is only four years old.

Each week, Mrs. San K. makes approximately US$ 35 in income and with the extra income from this loan she hopes to be able to meet the needs of the family and improve their living conditions. The two men shown in the picture came to take a loan instead of their wives because their wives were busy with their work. All the members are shown in the picture except one who is blocked.

This is a village bank loan consisting of a number of end-of-term loans. Seven members have end-of-term loans and the rest have monthly payment loans. These members are not required to pay any principal on the loan until the very end of the loan term. End-of-term (EoT) loans are AMK's main product because it is the most beneficial to Cambodia's poor. It allows them to repay portions of the principal whenever they are financially able to. Most clients start to make payments many months before the end of the loan term. Almost all of AMK's clients make their payments on time. AMK has a delinquency rate of only 0.09% and AMK has a default rate of 0% on Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to expand her inventory

loans.name: Bisabyaba Ahmed's Group, Bugolo

texts.en:
B. Ahmed is a married man with four children who are grown and have their own families, but he takes care of 3 grandchildren whose parents died of AIDS.

B. has been a fisherman all his life; it's the only business he has ever known. He fishes from Kikondo, a landing site in Lugazi, and sells his catch to traders and business people. In a round of fishing, he can catch and sell 20 basins of fish for about $5 each.

Ahmed has his own boat, which he has been using all this time, and he hopes to buy another boat that he can hire out for more income. He is seeking his first loan from Pearl Microfinance so he can improve his business by repairing his fishing net and the lights on his boat.

loans.use: Make repairs to his fishing net and the lights on his boat.

loans.name: Alex

texts.en: Alex T. M. is married and has 4 dependents. He has received schooling through primary level. Alex sells groceries like Milo, milk and other things at Kissi near Elmina, which he has done since 2006. His wife is a trader. Alex uses his income to take care of the family's financial needs. Alex will use the loan to purchase more Milo, milk, sugar and others things for his shop. With the new profits from his expanded business, Alex plans to invest in his children's education.

loans.use: Alex will use the loan to purchase more Milo, milk, sugar and others items

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
La señora Julia, desde hace 6 años, es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres al progreso de Juli”. Estudió el cuarto grado de Primaria, es casada, madre de 9 hijos y vive en la Comunidad de Vilcallami, distrito de Juli, provincia de Chuchito, departamento de Puno.

Con el primer préstamo de S/.300 que recibió, compró lana y bayeta para bordados. 

Compra y vende artesanía (bordados) para llevar a Puno, al mismo tiempo se dedica a la crianza de animales menores. Hoy sigue con la misma actividad económica. 

Con este préstamo de S/.600, el cual será cancelado en 4 cuotas, comprará lana y bayeta, también invertirá en la crianza de pollos.

Su único deseo es seguir adelante con su negocio.
texts.en:
Julia has been a member of the "Mujeres al progreso de Juli" communal bank for 6 years. She studied until the fourth grade, is married and a mother of 9 children. She lives in the community of Vilcallami, Juli district, Chuchito Province, in the department of Puno. With her first loan of 300 Nuevo Soles she purchased wool and cloth for embroideries. She buys and sells handicrafts (embroideries) to take to Puno and also works raising baby animals. With this loan of 600 Nuevo Soles, which will be repaid in 4 months, she will purchase wool and cloth. She will also invest in raising chickens. Her only desire is to continue ahead with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Donald Allen, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wool and cloth for embroideries, as well as investing in raising chickens

loans.name: Modieré

texts.fr:
Madame Modieré Sidibé est une femme mariée de 32 ans qui est mère de 6 enfants. Elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants  dans une famille monogame dans le quartier Hérémakono Centre de Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame Modieré Sidibé fait  comme activité génératrice de revenus de la restauration. Elle a son restaurant sis à la gare routière de Bougouni.  Elle mène cette activité depuis 10 ans qu’elle a appris  auprès de soeur. Elle cuisine des plats alimentaires de diverses sortes qui sont très appréciés par les routiers et les employers travaillant à l’autogare routière.
Avant d’intégrer le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso, Madame Modieré Sidibé avait certaines difficultés pour méner à bien son activité de restauration à cause de la faiblesse de son fonds de roulement. Ayant fait la connaissance de Soro Yiriwaso à travers une association de femmes de son quartier avec qui est a bouclé trois prêts solidaires(prêt de groupe) elle est à son  sixième prêt individuel avec l’institution et ses affaires ont commencés à décoller. Tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés tant sur le plan collectif qu’individuel.
Avec ce prêt, elle veut acheter 10 chaises pour l’accueil de sa clientèle, quotidiennement divers sortes de condiments alimentaires et hebdomadairement 3 sacs de riz  . Elle s’approvisionnera à Bougouni auprès des commerçants de la place.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 30 000 FCFA. Avec ce bénéfice elle compte améliorer davantage son restaurant et achéter une parcelle à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Modieré Sidibé is a married woman of 32 and the mother of six children. She lives with her husband and children in a monogamous family in the Hérémakono Centre neighbourhood of Bougouni, Mali. Mrs. Modieré Sidibé runs a restaurant in order to make money. Her restaurant is located at the Bougouni bus station. She has been in business for 10 years, a business her sister taught her. She prepares a wide variety of dishes which travellers as well as bus station employees much appreciate. Before joining the Soro Yiriwaso credit program, Mrs. Modieré Sidibé had some difficulties with managing her restaurant because of a lack of capital. A neighbourhood businesswomen's association introduced her to Soro Yiriwaso with which she has already completed three group loans. This is her sixth individual loan with this institution and her business is starting to take off. She has repaid all her previous loans on time, both the group loans and the individual loans. She wants to use this loan to buy 10 chair to accommodate her customers, to buy various condiments daily, and three bags of rice weekly. She will make her purchases in Bougouni, from the merchants in the market. She expects monthly earnings of 30,000 FCFA. With these earnings she plans to further improve her restaurant and to buy land for a home.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy foodstuffs for her restaurant.

loans.name: Kotognontala Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Kotognontala est composé de neuf (09) femmes ayant en moyenne 41ans et 4 enfants, toutes mariées et vivant majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygamiques au quartier Bamanan kin de Markala préfecture de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali). Kotognontala s’est spécialisé dans le commerce de poisson et des condiments alimentaires .Après avoir correctement remboursé leur 1er prêt, ce groupe est à son deuxième prêt solidaire.
Ce prêt sera  utilisé pour acheter 10 paniers de poissons frais au bord du fleuve Niger, 500 sachets de glaces, 3 sacs de choux pommés, 4 sacs d’oignon et 2 sacs de sels iodés. Elles se  ravitaillent en poisson frais au bord du fleuve Niger, une partie de ce poisson est fumée à l’aide d’un fumoir et ou séchée. Les condiments sont achetés une fois par semaine à Siribala. Ces produits sont vendus à domicile, en ambulant et aux marchés de Kirango et de Diamarabougou (Markala) à une cliente composée de femmes et  d’hommes. 
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 35 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et aider les maris à subvenir aux charges de la famille.
texts.en:
The Kotognontala group is composed of 9 women with an average age of 41 and on average, 4 children. They are all married and most of them live in big polygamous families in the Bamanan Kin district of Markala, prefecture of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the republic of Mali). Kotognontala group members are specialized in selling fish and condiments. After having reimbursed their first loan correctly, this group is on their second group (solidarity) loan.

This loan will be used to buy 10 baskets of fresh fish along the banks of the Niger river, 500 bags of ice, 3 sacks of cabbages, 4 sacks of onions, and 2 sacks of iodized salt. They buy their fish along the banks of the Niger river, and then smoke or dry part of it. The condiments are purchased once a week in Siribala. These products are sold out of their houses, door-to-door, or in the marketplaces of Kirango and of Diamarabougou (Markala) to a clientele composed of women and men.

They expect to make an average monthly profit of 35,000 F CFA which will be used to make repayments on the loan and to help their husbands support their families.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fish and condiments for re-sale

loans.name: Sa Moeurn

texts.en:
Mrs. Sa Moeurn T. is 47 years old and she lives in Koun Tnaut village in Kampong Cham province. She and her husband, Mr. Sat Phat, are farmers who own a plot of land where they cultivate rice. They have five children, one of whom is a teacher in the local school, while another is recycling collector, and the others are enrolled in the local school.

Since their second child’s business is doing well, they want to expand it for their child. Thus, Mrs. Sa Moeurn T. decided to ask for a loan to buy a motorbike to pull a cart to transport recyclable goods to re-sell at the recycling factory. She hopes to increase the family income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to pull a cart to transport recyclable goods

loans.name: Pham Thi

texts.vi:
Chị Phạm Thị Hồng năm nay  50 tuổi, hiện chị đang sống tại huyện Ý Yên tỉnh Nam định cùng chồng và hai con. Chị tham gia Quỹ tình thương  từ năm 2002 và  vay vốn để đầu tư chăn nuôi lợn và làm mộc . Đến nay sau 6 năm tham gia Quỹ vay vốn làm ăn hiệu quả hiện tại gia đình chị đã có 1 xưởng  mộc chuyên  sản xuất bàn ghế và đồ dùng gia đình với thu nhập 5.500.000đ/ tháng
Vòng vốn tới chị mong muốn được vay 20.000.000đ để đầu tư mua 2 khối gỗ về phục vụ cho công việc sản xuất của gia đình.
texts.en:
Mrs. Pham Thi H. is 50 years old. She lives in Y Yen district, Nam Dinh province with her husband and two children. She has participated in TYM Fund since 2002 and borrowed money to invest in raising pigs and making furniture. To date, after 6 years of participation in the Fund, with effective use of loan, her family has a furniture workshop specialized in making tables, chairs and other home products with an income oof VND5,500,000 per month.

In this loan cycle, she wishes to borrow VND20,000,000 to buy 2 cubic meters of wood for the furniture-making business of the family.

Translated from Vietnamese by Tu Duong, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: By wood for furniture making business

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion S. is a 28-year-old mother of two. Her husband, J.C. Rey, is a laborer. When she got married, she started selling fruits and vegetables. Their income is not enough to support the needs of her growing kids. She joined ASHI (Ahon Sa Hirtap, Inc.) to get capital to start a new business. She applied for this loan to buy one piglet for fattening and to buy assorted ingredients such as milk, gelatin, peanuts, bananas, refined sugar, ice cubes and others to make "halo-halo" (or mixed fruits with shredded ice cubes), which is in demand in their place during summer. 
She dreams of expanding her pigpen in the future, to raise more pigs. She wants also to save money out of her food vending to sustain their daily needs. She hopes that through her loans availed of ASHI in partnership with Kiva, someday she will be able to discover her talent to engage in a more productive business.

loans.use: To buy pig for fattening and to buy assorted ingredients for food vending.

loans.name: Zamira

texts.ru: Замира Вахобова  1981 года рождения, замужем имеет 2 детей. Замира закончила университет , вышла замуж. После замужества  муж не пустил на работу. Она три года назад начала  печь блинчики и торты. Не далеко от ее дома есть кафе - бистро, она туда сдает  свои блинчики и торты. Она договорилась с ними на счет цены и условиями поставки. Почти три года она печет дома и из дому забирают ее товар. В 2004 году обратилась за кредитом на покупки муки и других необходимых продуктов для выпечки, и до сих пор получает кредит. Она благодарна что ее поддержали  и ее бизнес.
texts.en:
Zamira was born in 1981. She is married and has 2 children. After Zamira graduated college, she got married, and her husband forbade her to go to work. Three years ago, Zamira began to bake pies and cakes. Zamira sells her products to a nearby cafe. The cafe has been Zamira's client for all three years. In 2004, Zamira applied for her first loan to purchase flour and other baking products. She has been a good borrower ever since. She thanks her lenders for supporting her business!

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase baking products

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.ru: Рузиева Гулбахор торгует уже 7 лет. На полученный  кредит приобрела новый товар. Товар ей привозят поставщики , она сажает за прилавком сына или дочь, но когда они в школе она сама торгует. В ее магазине  есть разнообразные товары. На одной стороне материалы, на другой стороне продукты питания. Она благодарна за поддержку , потому что благодаря кредиту она расширила свой бизнес и увеличила товарооборот.
texts.en:
Gulbahor R. has been selling for 7 years now. She used her loan to purchase new products. Her suppliers bring her the products, she sits her son or daughter behind the counter, but when they are in school she trades herself. Her store has a variety of products. On one side are materials and on the other side are food products. She is grateful for the support, because thanks to the credit she has grown her business and increased her turnover.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Grow business

loans.name: Guillermina

texts.es: La señora Guillermina tiene 60 años.  Ella se dedica a proveer de materiales para las oficinas de las Fuerzas Armadas, Camara de Diputados y Algunos Ministerios del Estado.  Ella es divorciada y cuenta con 2 (dos) hijos ya mayores quienes la ayudan en el trabajo. La misma se iniciò con una oficina en la Ciudad de San Lorenzo y ahora ya esta continuando con su actual emprendiendo  de abrir la segunda oficina en el interior del paìs. El crédito será de ayuda para seguir adelante con su negocio, y poder ampliar su empresa.
texts.en:
Guillermina is 60 years old. She provides office supplies to the offices of the Armed Forces, Legislature and some of the State Departments. She is divorced and has 2 grown children who help her with her job. She began her business with an office in the city of San Lorenzo and she continues it now by opening a second office in the interior of her country. The loan will help her move her business forward and allow her to expand her company.

Translated from Spanish by Rachel Crouch, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Office supplies like folders, paper, envelopes, etc.

loans.name: José Alexander

texts.es: José Alexander T. M. reside en San Juan Opico ubicado en el departamento de La Libertad, José tiene 32 años de edad vive con su esposa y sus dos hijos Katia de 6 años y Emanuel de 4 años de edad. José y su esposa tienen una pequeña tienda ubicada en su casa con productos de consumo y también se dedican a la crianza de pollos de engorde, José está solicitando este crédito por que quiere comprar más pollos y concentrado, para lograr aumentar sus ventas y satisfacer la demanda de sus clientes por los pollos que cría en su pequeña granja.
texts.en:
José Alexander T. M. lives in San Juan Opico in the department of La Libertad. José is 32 years old and lives with his wife and their two children: Katia, who is six years old, and Emanuel, who is four. José and his wife have a small store in their home, where they sell food; they also raise chickens. José is requesting this loan because he wants to buy more chickens and chicken feed so that he can sell more and fulfill his customers' demands for the chickens he raises on his small farm.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy chickens to fatten up

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es: La señora Nancy, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mas que Vencedoras II”, Distrito de Tarapoto, Provincia de San Martín, Departamento de San Martín. Es conviviente, tiene 39 años y 03 hijos, los tres que aun dependen de ella.Su espíritu  alegre y las ganas de generar sus propios ingresos, le motivaron a emprender su propio negocio de venta de Juanes, humitas y tamalitos, ubicada en su misma casa. En la actualidad tiene clientes fijos que a diario acuden a su casa a comprar sus juanes ya que tiene  una sazón muy rica y sus clientes ya la conocen, es  ella  misma quien personalmente les atiende  con el carisma que le caracteriza. Con este préstamo de S/. 500.00, desea invertirlo comprando sacos de arroz y maíz, aceites en docenas, huevos en javas, hojas de bijao en rollos, kilos de maní  y artículos de higiene personal como servilletas, cucharitas descartables de plásticas y así continuar dando una mejor atención a sus clientes. Nancy, se siente con mucha fuerza aun para continuar trabajando, y perseverando día a día y agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades de desarrollarse en el medio donde se desenvuelven.
texts.en:
Ms Nancy belongs to the community bank "Mas que Vencedoras II" (translated as "More than conquerors II") in the district of Tarapoto, in the province of San Martin. She is 39 years old and has three children, with all of them still depending on her. Her happy spirit and desire to generate her own income motivated her to undertake her own business selling food (juanes, humitas and tamalitos) made in her own house. Currently, she has regular clients that daily come to her house to buy food since it has a delicious flavor and her clients already know her well. She herself personally attends to her clients with a charisma that characterizes her. With this loan of $175, she wants to invest it by buying sacks of rice and corn, oil, eggs, leaves in rolls, kilograms of peanuts and household kitchen items like napkins, plastic disposable teaspoons so that she can continue giving better service to her clients. Nancy feels strong about continuing to work and persevering day after day. She is grateful for the Manuela Ramos movement for helping women like her to have opportunities to develop in the midst of where they are.

Translated from Spanish by Julie Lutz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for food preparation

loans.name: Abudacar

texts.en:
Abudacar is 30 years old and is a native of the Mozambican capital, Maputo. He has been employed as a driver by the ANES organization for the past seven months. He has been a licensed driver for the past six years. Before becoming a driver, Abudacar studied through the 10th grade and then tried his luck at a soccer career but was unsuccessful. 

Abudacar is requesting this loan to help finance the construction of his home. This will be the third loan he has taken out with Hluvuku for this motive. The previous loans have been successfully paid back and put to good use. As a driver, Abudacar receives around MT 3,500.00 a month and is able to save a small amount each month in a savings account at BIM bank. 

Abudacar is married and the father of two children, ages three and six. His wife is employed as a hairdresser. Abudacar's dream is to finish construction of his home and to continue to work to provide better living conditions for his family. 

About housing loans in Mozambique: In rural Mozambique many people still do not live in proper homes. Years of civil war and economic shock have inhibited residents from accessing capital and buying building materials for their homes. The last several years have been relatively prosperous and many residents are using microfinance as a means to commence construction of their home.

loans.use: To purchase construction Materials

loans.name: Patricio

texts.es:
El señor Patricio Z. ya ha tenido cuatro créditos con FVP y un con Kiva los cuales a pagado puntual mente, con los cuales ha realizado mejoras a su casa. 
Nueva mente está solicitando un préstamo para poder elaborar la barda lateral de su casa ya que su hijo está creciendo y necesita más seguridad. Pero en este momento no cuanta con el dinero necesario para poder comprar el material ya que el se encargara de realizar la mejora en horario adicional a su trabajo, ya  que se dedica a la construcción de casa. 
Este el ingreso que genera para su familia y con el cual una parte lo utiliza para pagar el préstamo.
texts.en:
Señor Patricio Z. has so far had four loans with FVP and one with Kiva. These have made it possible for him to make improvements to his house and he has made his payments punctually every month. Now he is seeking a new loan so he can build a side wall on his house since his son is growing up and he needs better security. However, he currently doesn't have the money he needs to buy the materials and he has to deal with making the improvements so it doesn't interfere with his work schedule. He does construction work building houses. This is how her earns his income for his family and part of that will be used to pay back the loan.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Kvaka, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To build a wall on his house.

loans.name: Concepcion

texts.en:
Concepcion S. of Sitio Cagay 4, Brgy. Buenavista, Escalante City, Negros Occidental is 69 years old, married with 7 adult children whose ages range from 31 to 44 years old.

Concepcion and her family earn their living through sugarcane farming and growing and selling vegetables, which nets an average income of PHP 12,000 per month. Negros Island is known as the sugarbowl of the Philippines; in past years, when sugar prices were relatively high, most of the farmers just concentrated on this monocrop industry. But now that costs of farm inputs (fertilizers, etc.) have gone up and the price of sugar has plummeted, many farmers are diversifying to crops that have a faster turnover. This is why Concepcion and her family grow vegetables: namely, so that they will have a regular cash flow which can better support their daily needs.

For her 14th loan cycle from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Concepcion is borrowing PHP 19,500 to purchase fertilizer to sustain the viability of her small farm.

About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. These women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: purchasing fertilizer

loans.name: Ana Consuelo

texts.es: La señora Ana Consuelo, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Mi Sueño”, Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. Es Conviviente, tiene 30 años y es madre de 03 hijos, que aun dependen de ella y por los que cada día se empeña en seguir adelante.Ana Consuelo, es una mujer trabajadora y luchadora que decidió vender comida, en un ambiente muy bien acondicionado, ubicado en su misma casa, ella nos cuenta que a diario tiene muy buenas ventas, es conocida por la sazón rica que le da a sus preparados y sus principales clientes son los mismos trabajadores de este centro de salud y moradores.En la actualidad, continúa con el mismo negocio y esta muy contenta con el trabajo que realiza día a día, en las mañanas de 10:00 am a 1:30 pm. Es ella quien personalmente atiende a sus clientes con el carisma que le caracteriza.Con este préstamo de S/ 2,000.00, comprará insumos para la preparación diaria de sus alimentos como arroz en kilos, azúcar; aceites en galones, sacos de papa, pollos en javas, verduras y también  algunos utensilios  para implementar su negocio y dar una mejor atención a sus clientes. Se siente llena de vida y con ganas de seguir adelante aun, tiene muchos sueños y metas en su vida. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por contribuir  en iniciar su negocio.
texts.en:
Sra. Ana Consuelo is a member of the Communal Bank “Mi Sueño” (My Dream), which is located in the District of Juanjui, Mariscal Cáceres Province, Department of San Martín. She is 30 years old, in a common law marriage, and the mother of 3 dependent children. She is committed each day so that her can children can succeed.

Ana Consuelo is a hardworking, strong-willed woman who decided to sell food. She operates out of her home, which is well-equipped for handling her business. Her sales have been good because her meals are known for having a rich flavor. Her main customers are local residents and workers at a nearby health clinic. The business continues to do well and she is happy with the work she does every day, which runs from 10am to 1:30pm. She attends to each of her customers with her friendly personality.

With this loan of 2000 soles, she will buy supplies for her daily food preparation such as rice in kilos, sugar, oil by the gallon, sacks of potatoes, cases of chicken, vegetables, and utensils. These items will keep her business running and help her provide better service to her customers.

Ana Consuelo is full of life and eager to move forward. She still has many dreams and goals in life, so she would like to thank Manuela Ramos for helping her start her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies for preparing meals

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Maria tiene 18 años, es una jovencita muy alegre y trabajadora, vive en la casa de sus padres y tiene muchas ganas de sobresalir en la vida. Aunque es muy joven, no quiere ser una carga para sus padres, es por eso que ha decidido trabajar en la empresa familiar y ganar su propio dinero. Ella trabaja confeccionando zapatos junto a sus padres y hermanos, los cuales luego lleva a vender en el puesto que tienen en el mercado San José (mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca). Lo que más le gusta a Maria de su trabajo es diseñar nuevos modelos de zapatos. Lleva 2 años en esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es trasladar los zapatos hasta su puesto de venta porque por la cantidad que lleva es una carga pesada. Para el futuro anhela tener su propia empresa de calzado, con la cual pueda ganar su dinero y formar una familia.
Este es el tercer préstamo de Maria con MFP, sabe que tiene que pagar todas sus cuotas a tiempo y está dispuesta a hacerlo. En su banco comunal es una socia muy respetada por la responsabilidad que demuestra. Con los mil doscientos nuevos soles solicitados comprará nuevos materiales para confeccionar más zapatos.

loans.use: Compra de materiales para elaborar zapatos

loans.name: Barikissou Akankè

texts.fr: T. Barikissou Akankè est née le 30/12/1975 à Cotonou, Capitale Économique du Bénin. Barikissou Akankè est mariée à AHOUNOU Raoul. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés et encore à sa charge. Barikissou Akankè a étudié jusqu'au secondaire mais actuellement, elle est dans le commerce. Barikissou Akankè est en effet dans la quincaillerie. Barikissou Akankè vend ses articles dans une boutique sise au quartier Sènadé de Cotonou. Mais, Barikissou Akankè vit avec sa famille à Suru-Léré toujours à Cotonou. Barikissou Akankè participe aux charges de la famille grâce au revenu de son activité. Barikissou Akankè achète ses articles au Nigeria, État voisin du Bénin. Barikissou Akankè a déjà bénéficié d'un prêt de ALIDé pour le compte de son activité, qu'elle a bien remboursé. Pour continuer de développer son activité, Barikissou Akankè sollicite un deuxième crédit de ALIDé pour renforcer son fonds de roulement.
texts.en:
Barikissou Akanke T. was born on December 30, 1972 in Cotonou, the Capital city of Benin. Barikissou Akanke is married to Raoul Ahounou. The couple have five children and they are all going to school and they are all still in their care. Barikissou Akanke completed high school but currently she is running a business. Barikissou Akanke runs a hardware store. Barikissou Akanke sells her products in a store located in the Senade district of Cotonou. But Barikissou Akanke lives with her family in the Suru-Lere district of Cotonou. Barikissou Akanke is able to provide for her family thanks to the revenues from her business. Barikissou Akanke purchases items for resale in Nigeria, a neighboring country of Benin. In the past Barikissou Akanke has had a loan from Alide (Kiva Field Partner) to benefit her business, and she repaid it on time. In order to continue to develop her business, Barikissou Akanke is requesting a second loan from Alide, to replenish the working capital funds.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase hardware store items ( Achat d'articles de quincaillerie (locks, keys, door handles, etc.)

loans.name: Leah Nechesa

texts.en:
Leah is 37 years old, married and blessed with three children. She runs a poultry business located at Junction in Eldoret, and makes her money selling eggs. Leah was introduced to KADET by a friend who was already a member, and has applied for a loan to expand her business by buying feed for her flock. She dreams of  improving her standard of living and making her business larger and more successful.

About KADET: 
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is dedicated to economically empower her clients by providing financial services to improve living conditions of micro-entrepreneurs and their children across Kenya. KADET is the microfinance subsidiary of World Vision Kenya. Obtain more information on KADET from the website: www.kadet.co.ke

loans.use: To buy feed for her chickens

loans.name: Gina

texts.en:
Gina D. is from the village of Mambajao, Camiguin. She is 37 years old. Gina is married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Gina owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector operating a clothing business selling ready-to-wear items to local community members. Gina also runs a food vending business. 

Gina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Gina is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and working capital. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Gina from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to meet the needs of her family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Additional inventory & working capital.

loans.name: Unidas Para El Progreso 1-3 Group

texts.en:
Maria, 43, is a borrower who lives near San Pedro de Macorís, Dominican Republic. She is the coordinator for her group, Unidas para el Progreso (United for Progress), and her story is representative of the other borrowers in the group.

Maria and her husband have nine children, ages six to twenty-three, all of whom live in their home. She and her family live in Batey El Fao, a small rural community northwest of San Pedro. Bateyes are small communities built by sugar companies for their workers. They typically have poor housing, scarce electricity, and unreliable running water that is never potable. With the profits from her business over the years, Maria has been able to construct her own home from cement block, a significant improvement over the typical local home. 

This is Maria’s sixth loan with Esperanza. She plans to use the loan to purchase rice, beans, oil, and other staple foods for her small colmado, or general store. She came to Esperanza because she likes the borrowing model based on holistic development. Maria not only receives loans, but also savings and health services for her family, among other things. She hopes that with the profits from this loan, she will move closer to her dream of sending her children to college. With your help, Maria can reach that goal. Thank you for lending to Maria and the Unidas para el Progreso group!

loans.use: To buy rice, beans, oil, plantains, and other foods

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia N. is from the village of Catarman , Camiguin Province. She is 52 years old. Virginia is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Virginia owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Virginia has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Virginia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Virginia is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Virginia from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Daynor

texts.es:
El señor Daynor Correón vive en casa en anticretico, en la zona  de San Antonio, ladera este de la ciudad de La Paz.
El señor Daynor trabaja como empleado de la administración publica.
El crédito solicitado es para la adquisición de una vivienda social que será pagada a plazos, pero que requiere el aporte de una cuota inicial para su adjudicación.
Esta es la primera vez que solicita préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Mr. Daynor Correón lives in a home under the “anticretico” rule. (Anticretico is a unique, legal method of housing in which the owner of the building allows a person to live for a determined amount of time in exchange for a set amount of money, which will be returned at the end of the living period.) He lives in the San Antonio zone, east of the city of La Paz. Mr. Daynor is a public administration employee. The loan that he is soliciting is to help him obtain social housing that will be paid for in installments, but requires an initial down payment. This is the first time he has asked for a loan but the socioeconomical analysis that was performed qualifies him favorably and he can access a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Emma Felten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Down payment for the purchase of a home

loans.name: Jawad

texts.en:
Jawad is a 44-year-old man who lives in Tyre in southern Lebanon. He lives with his wife and their four children. Jawad has been working in construction for a few years now. He actually owns an excavator that he uses for his work. He requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase fuel for his excavator. Jawad has been a microcredit client for eight years now, and he has always paid on time.

Jawad's clients are mainly construction workers. When Jawad first started his work, he wasn't really known by the people in his region. He decided on doing his own business, because he wanted to have independent work. In the future, he plans on improving his work.

loans.use: To purchase fuel for his excavator

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy more fresh fish in bulk

loans.name: Koreti

texts.en:
Koreti P. is 26 and married with 2 children (ages 1-month and 3yrs).  She owns a business venture, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Koreti has 5 years of experience in this business.  Koreti needs a loan of WST $800 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 300 talas or US $125 per week) to improve/expand the business.

You can view pictures of a typical plantation in Samoa, taken by a Kiva Fellow, at: http://picasaweb.google.com/agnes.p.chu/SamoanPlantation

In 2007, Koreti joined SPBD.    This is her 3rd loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Koreti's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Koreti P. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                         1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:            1.8 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:                2.3 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Sabah

texts.en: Sabah is a 54 year old widow woman who lives in Beirut, capital of Lebanon. Sabah has owned a grocery store since 2009. She sells canned food, candies, cleaning products, shampoos etc… Sabah requested a loan from Al Majmoua in order to purchase merchandise for her store. Sabah has been a microcredit client for eleven years now and has always paid on time. Sabah is special in her work because she knows how to treat her clients. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. When she first started her business, she had to face some financial issues. Sabah decided on doing her business because of her networking in her region. In the future, she plans on improving her work.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Las Intelectuales Y Responsables Group

texts.en:
Rosa is the coordinator of her group Las Intelectuales y Responsables (The Intelligent and Responsible Ones), and her story is representative of her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican (many of whom recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients generally. Her group is located in the rural areas surrounding La Romana, an area where the economy focuses around sugarcane and where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unreliable. She makes her home here in a simple structure with her long-term partner and their three children.

Rosa is excited to be taking her second loan with Esperanza, a Kiva partner, after having successfully repaid her previous loan and grown her business. She plans to use this loan to invest in her business selling underwear, sheets and clothing by traveling to the capital to purchase her goods and then returning to her community to sell them at a profit. She will use the profits to cover the day-to-day needs of her children. She thanks you all for your support.

loans.use: Underwear, sheets and clothing

loans.name: Luis

texts.es: El señor A. V. tiene 3 años de trabajar con esta institución financiera con la responsabilidad de deudor, en esta ocasión se le otorgo un crédito para la compra de terneros de desarrollo. Actualmente habita en la comarca Cofradía, Santa Rosa del Peñón, se dedica a la actividad agropecuaria contando con su propia finca y asimismo su ganado. Es necesario mencionar que tiene 52 años de experiencia de trabajar en las actividades agropecuarias.
texts.en:
Mr. A. V. has been involved with this finance institution for three years as a loaner. This time he is receving a loan to purchase calves to raise. He lives in Santa Rosa del Peñón, in the province of Cofradia, he is a farmer and a cattleman, with his own farm and own cattle, with 52 years of experience in this activities.

Translated from Spanish by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of calves to raise

loans.name: Reyna Maria

texts.es:
La señora B. S. tiene 4 años de trabajar con ceprodel es Madre soltera con dos hijos a su cargo en edad escolar, esta señora antes era ama de casa pero su esposo le regaló cinco mil córdobas para que ella se ayudara y pusiera algún negocio en su casa decidio venirse a vender al mercado en el callejon de las verduras frente al sector cerdo puso un negocio de verduras y marisco.
Ella empezo su negocio con poca mercaderia poco a poco ha salido adelante ahora tiene una ventesita en su casa que esa la administra su hija la mayor su casita la ha mejorado poco a poco tambien. Ahora solo  ella es  el sustento de su casa ya que no cuenta con su esposo por que falleció hace poco.
texts.en:
La señora B. S. tiene 4 años de trabajar con ceprodel es Madre soltera con dos hijos a su cargo en edad escolar, esta señora antes era ama de casa pero su esposo le regaló cinco mil córdobas para que ella se ayudara y pusiera algún negocio en su casa decidio venirse a vender al mercado en el callejon de las verduras frente al sector cerdo puso un negocio de verduras y marisco. Ella empezo su negocio con poca mercaderia poco a poco ha salido adelante ahora tiene una ventesita en su casa que esa la administra su hija la mayor su casita la ha mejorado poco a poco tambien. Ahora solo ella es el sustento de su casa ya que no cuenta con su esposo por que falleció hace poco.

Translated from Spanish by Alex J, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Para comprar mariscos y verduras para  mi negocio

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying grocery items

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en:
Emelia S. is from the city of Gango Ozamiz City. She is 57 years old, married, and has three adult-aged children. To make a living, she prepares and sells cooked food for daily meals. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately $215 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Emelia joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells. This will be her 1st loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she sells

loans.name: La Segunda Rosa Group

texts.es:
Esta foto fue tomada en la casa de la Sra. Ángela del Carmen S., presidenta del grupo La Segunda Rosa, que está ubicado en el Estado de Puebla en México.  Se ve en la foto a las integrantes del grupo así como los adornos típicos de la festividad del pueblo.   Ella se dedica a la cría de ganado ovino y a la venta de maíz cultivado por ella y su esposo. Considera que no hay mejor trabajo que la agricultura y la cría de animales domésticos.  Al momento de solicitar el préstamo se siente agradecida ya que por su condición económica y edad considera que es muy difícil que le otorguen un préstamo.  A sus 66 años casada y sin estudios, tiene 9 hijos (5 hombres y 4 mujeres) de los cuales solo uno de ellos depende de ella económicamente ya que aun se encuentra estudiando.   Solicita el préstamo para  poder comprar alimento para su ganado ovino, fertilizantes y comprar más animales para cría y vender.   También espera que con sus ganancias pueda seguir ayudando a su hijo en sus estudios y seguir siendo una persona productiva.
El grupo está conformado por  10 integrantes las cuales son:

María Luisa P			Vta. De ropa
Mercedes R.			Vta. De ropa
Teresa M.			Vta. De maíz
Felipa Josefina L.		Vta. De tortilla
Laura Vianeis R.		Vta. De desayunos
María Noelia V.			Vta. De calzado
Lidia Silvia T.			Vta. De tortilla
Ventura G.			Vta. De desecho industrial
texts.en:
This photo was taken in the house of Sra. Ángela del Carmen S., president of the Segunda Rosa group which is located in the state of Puebla, Mexico. In the photo the members of the group can be seen as well as decorations typical of the town. Ángela raises sheep and also sells the corn which she and her husband grow. She believes that there’s no better work than farming and raising livestock. She knows it is difficult to ask for a loan at this time given her economic situation and age, so she is grateful that the money will be granted to her. Ángela is 66 years old, married, and has no education. She has nine children (five sons and four daughters), only one of whom is still dependent on her as he is a student. The loan she is asking for will be used to buy animal feed, fertilizer, and more animals to raise and sell. She also hopes that with the profits she will be able to continue helping her son with his studies and continue being a productive member of society. The group is comprised of the following ten members: María Luisa P (clothing S.)  Mercedes R. (clothing S.)  Teresa M. (corn S.)  Felipa Josefina L. (tortilla S.)  Laura Vianeis R. (breakfast S.)  María Noelia V. (shoe S.)  Lidia Silvia T. (tortilla S.)  Ventura G. (industrial waste S.)

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy animal feed, fertilizer, and more animals

loans.name: Florentina

texts.es:
Florentina es socia del Bancomunal Ccori Soncco, tiene 55 años, es madre de 4 hijos, todos mayores de edad.
Florentina se dedica a la atención de un Laboratorio de Análisis, ya que su esposos es Médico Tecnólogo y ella le ayuda.
Florentina menciona que no tuvo dificultades en su negocio ya que fueron creciendo poco a poco. El préstamo que esta solicitando lo va ha invertir en la compra de tubos térmicos, sobres, formatos y ordenes medicas.
Ella menciona que las capacitaciones que recibe en su bancomunal de Finca Perú son muy interesantes, porque le enseñan a invertir correctamente el dinero que recibe.
El sueño de Florentina es que sus hijos sean profesionales. Comprarse una casa propia e instalar ahí una Clínica con diferentes áreas de atención.
texts.en:
Florentina is member of the Communal Bank “Ccori Soncco”. She is 55 years old and the mother of four adult children.

Florentina spends her time doing laboratory analysis. Her husband is a medical technologist and she works as his assistant. Florentina mentions that she has not had difficulties with her business because she and her husband have been able to grow it slowly. The loan she is requesting will be used to buy thermal tubes, envelopes, and medical order forms.

Florentina says that the training that she receives from FINCA Peru through her Communal Bank is interesting because the members are taught how to correctly invest the money they receive. She hopes to see her children become professionals. Florentina also wants to buy a house and establish a clinic that provides different types of care.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase thermal tubes, envelopes, and medical forms

loans.name: Luz De San Antonio Group

texts.es:
LUZ D. SAN ANTONIO

Este grupo se caracteriza por el compañerismo que existe entre ellas las once mujeres, salir adelante no ha sido fácil para cada una D. ellas; sin embargo es admirable ver el trabajo que hacen para no dejar D. faltar la economía en sus hogares tal es el caso D.: 
Giovana es una mujer D. 34 años, viste D. chaleco azul en la fotografía y es la tesorera del grupo.
Como toda madre quiere darle lo mejor a sus hijos, por ello decidió vender zapatos para adultos y niños a la edad D. 30 años, los ofrecía a sus conocidos D. su zona que vive, le fue bien al comienzo pero la competencia surgió en la que tuvo que cambiar D. negocio e iniciar en la venta D. gaseosas, tuvo un pequeño capital D. S/. 60.00 nuevos soles. Este último negocio resultó más rentable; es así que compró la refrigeradora que necesitaba para su negocio. Aprovecha D. esta artefacto para hacer además chupetes D. fruta que ella misma prepara en casa y son muy deliciosos D. varios sabores: lúcuma, mango, fresa.

Ha conseguido hasta el momento con los créditos recibidos invertir más en su negocio con el propósito D. apoyar a su pareja en la educación D. sus hijos con las ganancias que obtiene. Tiene dos hijos uno va a la escuela (16 años) y su hijo mayor es especial D. 17 años, lo ayuda en su tratamiento.
Las ganancias superan a lo que vendía en un inicio.
El crédito será para destinarlo en bebidas y agua mineral.
Tener una pequeña tiendita está en los planes D. Giovana que espera alcanzar no muy lejano.
texts.en:
"LUZ D. SAN ANTONIO" (Saint Antonio's Light) GROUP This group is characterized by the camaraderie that exists amongst the eleven ladies that make up its membership. Getting ahead has not been easy for any of them. Never the less it’s admirable to see the work that they each do in order that their homes are not in need. Such is the case with: Giovana, seen wearing a blue vest in the photograph, is 34 years old and is the group’s treasurer. Like every other mother, she wants to proviD. the best for her children, so at age 30 she decided to sell adults’ and children’s shoes to her acquaintances within the zone where she lives. Things were going well for her at first, but then the competition surged and she had to change her business and begin selling soft drinks instead. She had a little working capital, 60 PEN, to start with, but this new business has been more profitable than the previous one, so she was able to buy the refrigerator that she needed. She also uses [the refrigerator] to her advantage and makes and sells frozen, homemaD., fruit flavored popsicles. They are delicious and come in various flavors, including: Lucama (a type of tropical fruit), mango, and strawberry. Until now she has used the money from previous loans to invest in her business, with the intent of using the money from her income to help her husband pay for their children’s education. She has two children, one of whom is 16 years old and attends school, and the other, 17 years old, is a special needs child whom she helps with his treatments. Her income is greater than it was during her initial sales. She will use the money from this loan to invest in drinks and mineral water. Giovana plans to open a small store in the near future.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Inventory

loans.name: Alcides

texts.es:
El Sr. Alcides Baez de 42 años de edad, es divorciado, el tiene la dicha de tener 5 hijos.
 Don Alcides comenzó con esta profesión  aproximadamente en el año 1997; después de hacer varios cursos consiguió ser egresado de un instituto profesional, seguidamente habilitó un local para ofrecer sus servicios de corte de cabellos para hombres,  en la actualidad sus clientes asisten en forma regular a su negocio;  tiene una buena cantidad de clientela formada.
   El invertirá este crédito en la refacción de su local comercial, para crear un buen ambiente y ofrecer mejores servicios a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Mr. Alcides Baez is 42 years old, divorced, and joyful to be the father of five children. Alcides started his business in 1997, after taking courses and graduating from a professional school. He opened his own barbershop, and today, he has many regular customers. He will use this loan to renovate his barbershop, improve the atmosphere of the place, and offer better service to his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Violeta Rubiani, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Improvements to his business

loans.name: Maricel

texts.en: Maricel R. is from the village of Yumbing, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 33 years old, is single, and has four school-aged children. Maricel owns and operates a specialized retail store, selling and dealing in personal products such as clothes and shoes in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 9,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Maricel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Maricel is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory and used as working capital. This loan will be her 3rd from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventory and to use as working capital

loans.name: Elavil

texts.en:
Elavil L. is from the village of Bitibut Sapang Dalaga Misamis Occidental. She is 25 years old and married with two school-aged children. To make a living, Elavil owns and operates a canteen. The main source of income for the business comes from serving local foods, such as hot cake and ice candy, to customers in the local community. Elavil has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2010, Elavil joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Elavil is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw materials for making snack foods. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Elavil from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials for making snack foods

loans.name: Elvira Leticia

texts.es:
Elvira de 40 años, tiene una pequeña papelería en la parte delantera de su casa,  vive en  una zona urbana “Los Vergeles” caracterizada por la gran población de personas. Su esposo es chofer ellos tienen dos hijos de 17 y 11 años. 

Comenzó a vivir en vergeles desde que se caso, para poder ayudar a su esposo con los gastos familiares ella invirtió sus ahorros en papelería. Desde ese tiempo hasta ahora trabaja desde las 07h00am, vende todo tipo de papelería, aunque por donde vive los caminos son de tierra sigue trabajando para darles una mejor vida a su familia. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar papelería y artículos de papelería. En el futuro quiere arreglar mejor su casa y tener un departamento para alquilarlo.
texts.en:
Elvira, 40, has a small stationery shop in the front part of her house. She lives in an urban zone called “Los Vergeles” which is quite heavily populated. Her husband is a driver and they have two children who are 17 and 11 years old. She has lived in Vergeles since she got married. To help her husband meet family expenses she invested her savings in a stationery store. Since then and to the present day she works from 7am. She sells all kinds of stationery items. Although she lives in a neighborhood with unpaved streets she continues to work to give her family a better life. The loan will be used to buy stationery items. In the future she’d like to fix up her house better and own an apartment to rent out.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For paper goods.

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson Y., from the village of Poblacion 2 Clarin Misamis Occidental, is 43 years old, married, and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Samson has been planting and harvesting mangoes for sale for over 25 years, and earns approximately 30000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Samson joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid a previous loan of 50000 PHP from GDMPC, he is requesting a new loan of 50000 PHP to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be Samson's 18th loan from GDMPC, and he plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family.

About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase chemicals and materials for mango production

loans.name: Arlene's Group

texts.en:
Arlene P. is from Bagumbayan, Tuguegarao City. She is 46 years old. Arlene is the group leader of a 5-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Arlene is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Arlene owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling a variety of different products in the local community. Arlene has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Arlene joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Arlene is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand product offering. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Arlene from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Azucenas Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal  “Azucenas”  se conforma por 16 socias y 2 socios, pertenecientes a la comuna de la Cisterna. Sus principales negocios son la venta de verdura, lencería, ropa nueva y usada; producción y venta de berlines, comida rápida y colaciones,  y  confección de  sábanas.
Rosa es la presidenta de este grupo y en la foto se encuentra sentada en 1º fila de izquierda a derecha.  Ella cocina y  vende productos de pastelería, como por ejemplo pasteles y kuchenes, 2 veces a la semana en una feria cerca de su casa. Por encargos hace tortas y otros productos, en su casa. Además vende helados artesanales con barquillos y, a lo que se suma la confección de ropa en su casa, todos los días de la semana. Finalmente, aprovechando su horno industrial, el cual compró con otros préstamos de Fondo Esperanza, hace y vende empanadas y a veces pollo asado. 
Con este préstamo comprará pollos para hacer asados, y para preparar platos de colaciones y venderlos en la feria.  Con los préstamos recibidos de FE además del horno industrial,  Rosa adquirió su hielera para sus helados y un refrigerador para la casa de su mamá donde vive con sus 2 hijos menores, de 13 y 7 años, quienes junto a su hijo mayor de 21 (quien está en un internado de rehabilitación de drogas) son su motivación para seguir adelante con su negocio. Rosa recibe solo una pequeña ayuda económica de parte del padre de uno de sus hijos.  Su sueño es tener una panadería, en donde pueda vender productos de pastelería,  pollos asados y sus helados, en una parte de su casa propia que le entregarán por subsidio a fines del próximo año. 
A Rosa le ha gustado mucho trabajar con Fondo Esperanza, por la buena atención que ha recibido de parte de su asesora y por la pronta entrega de sus préstamos. Además agradece la educación sobre la administración de su negocio. 
La Cisterna es una comuna de Santiago, ubicada en el sector centro-sur de la capital chilena, y comprendida totalmente dentro del área urbana. Es una comuna esencialmente residencial y comercial.
texts.en:
The “Azucenas” communal bank is made up of 16 female and 2 male members, and they are from the town of Cisterna. Their main businesses are: the sale of vegetables, female undergarments, new and used clothing; the production and sale of pastries, fast foods, meals, and tailoring bed sheets. 
Rosa is the president of this group and in the photo she is seen sitting down in the first row from left to right. She cooks and sells bakery goods, like pastries and “kuchen” (pies), twice a week at a fair near her house. She makes made-to-order cakes and other products in her house. She also sells artisan ice cream on cones, and she tailors clothes in her house every day of the week. Finally, using her industrial oven that she bought with the other loans from Fondo Esperanza, she makes and sells empanadas (meat-filled pastries) and sometimes pollo asado (grilled chicken). 

With this loan she will buy chickens to make asados and to prepare meal plates to sell in the fair. With the loans she received from FE as well as from the industrial oven, Rosa acquired a freezer for her ice creams and a refrigerator for her mother’s house, where she lives with her two children ages 13 and 7. They, together with her 21 year old son (who is in a drug rehabilitation facility) are her motivations for pushing forward with her business. Rosa receives only a tiny bit of economic help from the father of one of her children. 

Her dream is to own a bakery where she can sell baked goods, grilled chicken and ice creams in a part of her own house that she will  get subsidized at the end of next year.

Rosa has very much enjoyed working with Fondo Esperanza, for the good attention she has received from the loan officer and for the quick disbursement of her loans. She also thanks the politeness of the administration of her business.

La Cisterna is a community in Santiago, located in the “centro-sur” (south central) sector of the Chilean capital, and inside of a completely urban zone. It is primarily a residential and commercial town.

loans.use: Chickens and other food goods.

loans.name: Baasanhuu

texts.en:
Baasanhuu R. is 43 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the Arhangai province of Mongolia. She and her family live together in an apartment. All three children attend a local school.

Baasanhuu operates a meat retail business in the local market in her town. She began her business in 2005 with working capital of 150,000 MNT. After several years of hard work and with a loyal customer base, her working capital now exceeds 700,000 MNT. 

Over the years, she has gained a significant experience and many permanent customers. She would like to expand their business in the future and own her own livestock. 

Baasanhuu is a hard-working and honest woman and is requesting a 700,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more meat to sell.

loans.use: To purchase more meat

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward is 30 years old and married to Gladys Chebet who is 26 years old. They have one child, Dennis Kiprono, who is three years old. Edward has five years experience in the video editing business that he and his wife operate. His clientele comprises middle and lower class clients who require video coverage, especially for celebrations like weddings, birthdays and other special days.

Edward has serviced another loan of KES 40,000 with KADET and has repaid successfully. This will be his second loan with which he will buy another video editing machine. The idea behind buying a better editing machine is to provide better quality photos and videos and to improve efficiency within his business. Edward, who attends evening classes, is hoping that with the new editing machine he will be able to clear more work and thus have time to attend his classes comfortably.

He wants to be able to provide for all of his family's basic needs.

loans.use: To buy a video editing machine

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is 38 years old and married with three children, all of whom are dependent on her and need her support. Rose lives with her family in the province of Rizal in the Philippines.  Her husband works long hours as a fisherman to support the family.  To supply additional income, Rose wants to expand the family fishing business through additional working capital. 

Rose would like to receive a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase fish nets, rope, and additional materials.  With additional equipment, Rose believes that her fish supply will increase, bringing higher revenue.

Over the course of her membership, Rose has achieved strong performance with regular attendance at group meetings and steady repayments.  Rose is thankful for access to capital and loans to support her entrepreneurial dreams. 

With the support of ASHI and Kiva, she is hopeful that their expanded business will continue to flourish to improve the family’s quality of life and fund all of her children’s college education.

loans.use: To purchase fish nets, rope, and additional materials needed in her fishing business

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en: Adjoa N. sells banku (corn or maize-based dumplings, commonly known by Fantes as etew) at Abura. She is married to a farmer and has seven dependants. Adjoa has been selling banku for three years. She assists her husband in the general welfare of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more ingredients to cook and sell, in order to expand her business. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her dependants.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to cook for sale.

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: From the province of Kompong Tom, Kim C. is a 52-year-old who makes her daily income by growing rice on her farm land. She inherited the land from her grandmother four years ago. She and her husband are working together in the farming business, and they usually get good results from their rice crop, in both rainy and dry seasons. For the last two months, Kim C. has been doing dry season rice cultivation but her crop is not growing well because of a lack of fertilizer. To deal with this problem, Kim C. would like to request a loan to buy sacks of fertilizer for her rice fields, and to pay for plowing costs. The couple has four children; one of them is single and three of them are married.

loans.use: To buy sacks of fertilizer for her crop, and to pay for plowing costs.

loans.name: Gemma

texts.en:
Gemma C., 44, is an entrepreneur with a knack for multitasking. She is a therapist/masseuse and a retailer of various products, and found success in both fields. Gemma raised her 2 kids alone.  She works hard to meet their family needs.  They presently live in Habitat, Baseco Port Area, Manila.

Being in the business of selling food to supplement her income, Gemma has developed the skills to choose quality products and deal with people in the neighborhood to turn them into regular customers. She also sells these items to her massage customers.   Her regular customers are her neighbors, the community, and other business connections. Monthly, she earns an average net income of Php11,800.  

Gemma wants to maximize her potential as a multitasking entrepreneur. To help her do that and grow her businesses, she is requesting a loan of Php10,000. She plans to use this fund to increase the number of products she sells in order to better meet the specific needs of her regular customers. 

Sure enough, Gemma has her share of customers who do not pay on time. Nevertheless, she still prays for the ability to collect their payments. All this multitasking is a means of preparing for the multi-faceted future which she wants her two children to have.
